descriptions.description: More maintainer time increases the rate at which issues can be resolved.
More open issues generate more feedback from users and contributors.
Increased feedback can lead to the identification of new issues, increasing the stock.
More open issues motivate contributors to submit new pull requests to address them.
The flow of new pull requests increases the stock of new pull requests awaiting initial processing.
New pull requests move into the review state as they are picked up by developers.
Reviewed and approved pull requests are merged, adding to the source code.
A larger backlog of pull requests under review can increase the rejection rate due to stricter standards.
More core developers reduces the average delay for pull request reviews.
Shorter review delays lead to faster and more frequent feedback on pull requests.
New contributors gain experience over time and become experienced contributors.
Experienced contributors are promoted to core developers based on their sustained involvement.
Experienced contributors provide more frequent and higher-quality PR feedback.
Positive PR feedback encourages new contributors to stay and join the project.
Effective PR feedback helps identify and cultivate potential core developers.
Timely PR feedback accelerates the movement of pull requests through the review process.
PR feedback, especially in discussions, adds valuable content to the searchable knowledge base.
More implicit knowledge increases the potential rate of its loss if not shared or documented.
A larger base of implicit knowledge facilitates its conversion into explicit forms.
More explicit knowledge provides a foundation for contributors to internalize it as implicit knowledge.
The conversion of explicit to implicit knowledge increases the stock of implicit understanding.
A larger stock of explicit knowledge improves the quality and completeness of documentation.
Better documentation lowers the barrier to entry, increasing the joining rate of new contributors.
Effective documentation accelerates the skill development of new contributors.
A rich base of implicit knowledge enables more effective mentorship.
Mentorship directly transfers skills, accelerating the skill-up process for contributors.
Effective mentorship prepares contributors for advancement, increasing the promotion rate.
More core developers increases the capacity for mentorship within the project.
A high number of open issues can discourage the creation of new, potentially redundant issues.
A large backlog of open issues can overwhelm maintainers, slowing the issue resolution rate.
Closed issues, with their solutions, become part of the project's searchable knowledge base.
Community discussions are archived and become a searchable resource for future problem-solving.
A comprehensive knowledge base is a primary source for the project's explicit knowledge.
A better project reputation makes it more attractive, increasing the joining rate of new contributors.
A strong project reputation attracts more users, growing the user base.
A healthy community, with positive interactions, enhances the project's overall reputation.
High-quality software with good features builds a positive reputation for the project.
The adoption rate flow adds new users to the user base stock.
The user churn rate flow removes users from the user base stock.
Positive project outcomes and community actions increase the project's reputation.
Negative events or poor software quality decrease the project's reputation.
Trust-building activities, like fair governance, strengthen the community's health.
Toxic interactions or burnout erode community norms and reduce community health.
Developer turnover reduces the number of core developers in the project.
The review rate flow moves pull requests into the 'under review' stock.
The merge/commit flow adds new, approved code to the source code stock.
The rejection rate flow removes pull requests from the 'under review' stock.
As new contributors skill up, they graduate out of the 'new contributor' stock.
The skill-up flow adds contributors to the experienced contributors stock.
The promotion rate flow adds experienced contributors to the core developer stock.
The promotion rate flow removes contributors from the experienced contributors stock.
A higher joining rate increases the stock of new contributors.
The depreciation/loss of knowledge flow reduces the stock of implicit knowledge.
The knowledge conversion rate flow adds newly documented knowledge to the explicit knowledge stock.
The explicit-to-implicit conversion flow reduces the explicit knowledge stock as it is internalized.
The issue creation rate flow adds new issues to the open issues stock.
The issue resolution rate flow moves issues from open to closed.
Community engagement, like forum posts, adds content to the searchable knowledge base.
